column5: Received a 50% refund of HST about 6 weeks after I filed for it. We had a housekeeping cabin and the service that qualified the refund was guiding. My local bank deducted 0 fees. The CDN$ is worth more than the US$ after all.

Last week I deposited into my account our HST rebate check of $225.88. This morning the bank notified me of the total charges for exchange rate and foreign transaction fees. The total was $1.49, less than 2/3 of 1%.For me, it sure isn't worth holding the check for a year, stopping at a Canadian bank on the way to next year's fishing, or driving across town to fuss about it. In fact, the charges are probably less than a telephone call to our outfitter to ask him to do something with it.One more thing I don't have to fret about as I anticipate next year's trip!

Not that I know of.

seems like your bank would soon go bankrupt with these negligible fees?? did you pay in US$, then get the check in Canadian $, then cash the check to get back to US$? there has to be an exchange cost somewhere along the line - nobody works for free. did the exchange rates vary over the time frame such that you only lost $1.49? this just doesn't sound right. banks here in PA not only charge an exchange rate fee (the "spread") but also a service fee - these are MUCH more than $1.49. phish

There is a reason for the two envelopes. I was in the mailing business for an insurance company and recently retired. We had to send multiple envelopes alot -- and not only made us look stupid but it also cost a lot of money.However, when you have an automated process (like the HST Checks) and a manual process (like the original receipt) there is no easy way to get them into a single envelope until a fully designed system is ready to do it. That programming and system developement take a lot of I/S time and resources. The bottom line is that it's more efficient (and probably less costly) to send two envelopes. But, it sure makes you look dumb.Tight lines!Port

Port -- not meaning to "beat a dead horse" - But, If I ran the gov't I would give the same office that handles (manually) the incoming refund requests the capability to issue the checks and THEN they could send everything back together at the same time. Yeah, I know - that's "trusting" too many people and also too efficient -- I understand.
